variant.question: Reducing wing aspect ratio will

options.text: Reduce the lift coefficient obtained for a given angle of attack and increase the critical angle of attack.
Increase the lift coefficient obtained for a given angle of attack and reduce the critical angle of attack.
Increase the lift coefficient obtained for a given angle of attack and increase the critical angle of attack.
Reduce the lift coefficient obtained for a given angle of attack and reduce the critical angle of attack.

variant.question: Decreasing the aspect ratio of a wing:

options.text: increases induced drag.
decreases induced drag.
increases gust load.
decreases stall speed.

variant.question: Increasing the aspect ratio of a wing:

options.text: decreases induced drag.
decreases gust load.
increases induced drag.
increases stall speed.

variant.question: For a tapered wing the aspect ratio is?

options.text: Wingspan squared / wing area
Wingspan squared * wing area
wing area / wing depth
wing depth * wing area

variant.question:
Wing twist (geometric and aerodynamic) is used to:

1. improve stall characteristics.2. reduce induced drag.3. reduce interference drag.4. increase VMO.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Aspect ratio of a wing is the ratio between:

options.text: Wing span squared and wing area.
Wing span and wing root chord.
Wing root chord line and wing tip chord line.
Wing span and dihedral angle.

variant.question: Aspect ratio of a wing is the ratio between:

options.text: wingspan squared and wing area.
wingspan and dihedral angle.
wingspan and wing root chord.
wing root chord line and wing tip chord line.

variant.question: Aspect ratio of a wing is the ratio between:

options.text: wing span and mean geometric chord.
tip chord and wing span.
mean geometric chord and root chord.
wing span and root chord.

variant.question: The mean geometric chord of a wing is the..

options.text: wing area divided by the wing span.
wing area divided by the mean aerodynamic chord.
wingspan squared divided by the wing area.
wingspan divided by the gross wing area.

variant.question: The angle of attack of a two-dimensional wing section is the angle between

options.text: the chord line of the aerofoil and the free stream direction.
the chord line of the aerofoil and the fuselage centreline.
the chord line and the camber line of the aerofoil.
the fuselage centreline and the free stream direction.

variant.question: The wing platform that gives a constant lift value along the whole area is...

options.text: elliptical.
tapered.
swept-back.
rectangular.

variant.question: The aspect ratio of a wing is the ratio between the:

options.text: wing span and the mean geometric chord.
wing span and the root chord.
chord and root chord.
tip chord and the wing span.

variant.question: High aspect ratio, as compared with low aspect ratio, has the effect of:

options.text: decreasing induced drag and critical angle of attack.
increasing lift and drag.
increasing induced drag and decreasing critical angle of attack.
increasing lift and critical angle of attack.

variant.question: The Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) for a given wing of any platform is basically:

options.text: the chord of an equivalent untwisted, rectangular wing with the same pitching moment and lift characteristics as the actual wing.
the chord of a large rectangular wing.
the wing area divided by the wingspan.
the average chord of the actual aeroplane.

variant.question: Dihedral of the wing is:

options.text: the angle between the 0.25 chord line of the wing and the lateral axis.
the angle between the 0.25 chord line of the wing and the vertical axis.
the angle between the 0.25 chord line of the wing and the horizon.
the angle between the leading edge of the wing and the lateral axis.

variant.question: If the wing area is increased, lift will:

options.text: increase because it is directly proportional to wing area.
remain constant.
not change because the lift coefficient is constant.
increase with the square of the wing area.

variant.question: Winglets

options.text: decrease the induced drag.
increase the manoeuvrability.
decrease the static lateral stability.
create an elliptical lift distribution.

variant.question: Considering a rectangular unswept wing, which statement is correct?

options.text: The flow on the upper surface of the wing has a component acting in the direction of the wing root.
Tip vortices can be diminished by vortex generators.
Tip vortices and induced drag decrease with increasing Angle Of Attack.
The flows on the upper and lower surfaces of the wing are both in the direction of the wing tip.

variant.question: Assuming zero wing twist, the wing planform that gives the highest local lift coefficient at the wing root is:

options.text: rectangular.
elliptical.
tapered.

variant.question: Assuming zero wing twist, the wing planform that gives the highest local lift coefficient at the wing root is:

options.text: rectangular
swept-back.
tapered.

variant.question: Winglets:

options.text: decrease the induced drag.
decrease the static lateral stability.
increase the manoeuvrability.
create an elliptical lift distribution.

both CL and CD increase.

the leading edge of the wing and the lateral axis.

options.text: angle of incidence.
glide angle.

options.text: Decrease induced drag
Increase alpha at the tip

options.text: equal to 1 or less than 1.
less than 1.
more than 1.
equal to 1.

options.text: drag increases but lift decreases.
drag increases but lift remains constant.
both drag and lift decrease.
both drag and lift increase.

variant.question: The span-wise flow on an unswept wing is from the:

options.text: lower to the upper wing surface via the wing tip.

upper to the lower wing surface via the wing tip.

variant.question: A high aspect ratio wing will:

options.text: Produce more lift but stall at a smaller alpha because the tip effect is less
Produce less lift but stall at a smaller alpha because the tip effect is less
Produce less lift and stall at a smaller alpha because the tip effect is greater
Produce more lift and stall at a higher alpha because the tip effect is greater

options.text: aircraft weight to wing area.
lift to wing weight.
wing area to wing weight.
lift to aircraft weight.

to increase lift at the tip, thus equalising lift across the wing.
to reduce lift at the tip, thus equalising lift across the wing.
to reduce induced drag caused by wing tip vortices.

options.text: an increase in the critical Mach number.
a decrease in the critical Mach number.
an increase in longitudinal stability.

variant.question:
Which of the following items are needed to correctly complete the statement? 
The characteristics of wing sweep include 
1 a decreased tendency to tip stall
2 increased take-off and landing distances
3 a higher stall speed
4 an increased effectiveness of trailing edge control surfaces
5 a decreased effectiveness of high lift devices.

options.text: 4 and 5

variant.question: Which of the following statement correctly describes wing fences?

options.text: Flat plates fixed to the upper surfaces parallel to the wing chord.
Flat plates fixed to the lower surface of a wing at a 45 degree angle to the wing chord.
Small vertical fin attached to the rear and bottom of a fuselage.
Flat plates fixed to the upper surfaces perpendicular to the wing chord.

variant.question: Which properties do swept wings have?

options.text: Less affected by turbulence and have a shallow CL v AOA curve
Less affected by turbulence and have a steep CL v AOA curve
More affected by turbulence and have a steep CL v AOA curve
More affected by turbulence and have a shallow CL v AOA curve

variant.question: Wing sweep has

options.text: A negative influence on stall characteristics, as it increases stalling speed and could cause tip stall.
A positive influence on the stall characteristic, as it increases controllability by the ailerons.
A positive influence on stall characteristic, as it provides positive pitch stability during a stall.
No influence on stall characteristics, as it is used only to increase the critical Mach number.

variant.question: The stalling angle of a wing:

options.text: is unaffected by a turn.
decreases in a turn.
increases in a high rate of turn.
decreases in a high rate of turn.

variant.question:
Which of these statements about the effect of wing sweep on centre of pressure location are correct or incorrect?
1) The centre of pressure on a straight wing moves aft as the angle of attack approaches and exceeds the critical angle of attack.
2) The centre of pressure on a strongly swept back wing moves forward as the angle of attack approaches and exceeds the critical angle of attack.

options.text: 1) is correct, 2) is correct.
1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.
1) is incorrect, 2) is correct.
1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.

variant.question: The "dihedral" construction feature of an aircraft wing provides an increase in:

options.text: lateral stability about the longitudinal axis.
lateral stability about the normal axis.
longitudinal stability about the lateral axis.
directional stability about the lateral axis.

variant.question: Wing dihedral:

options.text: contributes to static lateral stability.
is particularly applied on aeroplanes with high mounted wings.
does not affect static lateral stability.
is the only way of ensuring static lateral stability.

options.text: Roll the aircraft to the left
Pitch the nose back to the horizon

variant.question: The primary purpose of dihedral is to:

options.text: increase static lateral stability.
increase static directional stability.
decrease sensitivity to Dutch roll.

variant.question: The effect of a high wing with zero dihedral is as follows:

options.text: Positive dihedral effect
Zero dihedral effect
Its only purpose is to ease aeroplane loading
Negative dihedral effect

variant.question: Which of the following statements about dihedral is correct?

options.text: The effective dihedral of an aeroplane component means the contribution of that component to the static lateral stability.
Dihedral contributes to dynamic but not to static lateral stability.
Effective dihedral is the angle between the 1/4-chord line and the lateral axis of the aeroplane.
Dihedral is necessary for the execution of slip-free turns.

variant.question: What wing shape or wing characteristic is the least sensitive to turbulence?

options.text: Swept wings.
Straight wings.

variant.question: Wing flutter may be caused by a:

options.text: combination of bending and torsion of the wing structure.
combination roll control reversal and low speed stall.
aerodynamic wing stall at high speed.
